awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Higher-potency Insecticidal Dusts by Solid-State Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of insecticidal formulations that extend the life of current active ingredients that are failing due to widespread resistance. The development of resistance to exogenous insecticidal chemicals
forces the need to invent new active ingredients with new mechanisms of action. The goal of the proposed technology is to provide more effective formulations that may serve to repurpose existing insecticides that were earlier thought to no longer be effective.  Reformulating known insecticidal compounds to increase efficacy may be an alternative to the costly development of new active ingredients.  Further, reformulating known insecticidal compounds in more bioavailable forms may be cheaper, less risky, greener, and faster. Little engineering or research and development to replace existing products. The outcomes of this endeavor are broadly applicable to the control of urban pests, pet protection, agriculture, and public health.  Markets for new products extend from deadly mosquito control (malaria has been confirmed in the United States for the first time in decades) to bed bug eradication, or simple pet collars. Products commonly sold in hardware stores may be reengineered by the proposed process. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of insecticidal chemical formulations that employ activated crystalline forms of contact insecticides that have not been previously discovered. Contact insecticides that are the mainstays of pest control are failing due to widespread resistance among vector populations, a major public health challenge. Insecticide resistance also has been found in urban pests such as bedbugs and cockroaches. Insecticides that work on contact often involve crystals, but exploiting the relative activity of different crystals of the same compound has not been investigated. The proposed technology has been shown to overcome resistance among resistant malarial mosquitoes from West Africa. In this study, the common insecticide deltamethrin was reformulated to contain a new solid form of the active ingredient dispersed on chalk.  The new solid form is prepared in situ by a simple and inexpensive method that may enhance deltamethrin’s efficacy against a wide variety of arthropods.  The proposed technology may enhance the ability to eliminate insects with deltamethrin, and overcome organisms with vexing resistance that compromises disease prophylaxis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Bryan Erriah was the PhD candidate who spearheaded our I-Corps project, Higher-potency insecticidal dusts by solid-state transformations. Many insecticides, especially public health insecticides (mosquito adulticides) which first captured our attention, are contact insecticides, the function when vector borne insects walk on microcrystals of the toxicants. Bryan established that heating chalk with anti-malarial insecticides dispersed within, affected a transformation of the stable crystalline form of deltamethrin to a solid amorphous form that liberated its molecules more rapidly. In fact, in collaboration with the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, in advance of I-Corps, we should that our heating formulations could effectively overcome malaria transmitting mosquitoes from West Africa that had become resistant to the stable for the insecticide. This research was published in the Malaria Journal in 2023 and the process was patented US11,582,971 A1. Mr. Erriah, together with our business lead, Steven Isaacman of PhD Biosciences, La Jolla, CA, analyzed the possibility of using heated insecticidal dusts in the service of controlling urban pests such as bed bugs and cockroaches (dusts aren’t used foremost against malaria). Bryan led his cohort in interviewing potential customers. PhD Biosciences has licensed NYUs patent. And PhD Biosciences has written several SBIR/STTR proposals with the aim of getting the business off the ground. These proposals haven’t been awarded, and thus Bryan is now taking a job at McKinsey out of necessity, postponing the original ambition to build a company. Very interesting scientific questions have been generated. Foremost of Erriah’s discovery of the role of the calcite particle surfaces. When a leading insecticide is melting on single crystal plates of calcite, the melt of the toxicant phase separates into two amorphous forms, droplets within droplets, that seem to have different activities. This undoubtedly has something to do with our ability to compromise resistant mosquitoes.

 


Last Modified: 03/09/2025
Modified by: Bart E Kahr
